departments on the Homewood
campus will not offer any formal

limitations to professorial work

Prospects for an increase in
state assistance to private higher
education brightened
considerably yesterday, after
members of the Executive
Committee of the Maryland
Independent Colleges and
University Association met for
45 minutes with Governor
Marvin Mandel, according to
President Muller's Special
Assistant Ellery Woodworth.
"The Governor indicated he
was wholly prepared to accept
the Pear Report's fiscal
recommendations so long that
the money could be found to
finance it," Woodworth said.
"And, I think I can say we
came away from the meeting
very encouraged," Woodworth
added.
The Pear Report proposed that
the state contribute $1.8 million
above and beyond the current $3
million to 16 private colleges in
Maryland. Hopkins would realize
$1.5 million under the Pear
formula, compared with
$963,000 under existing
programs.
Though Muller was unable to
attend the meeting with Mandel,
Woodworth represented him.

Woodworth is also Executive
Secretary of the Maryland
Council for Higher Education,
which commissioned the Pear
Committee to study state
funding of private college.
Also at the meeting with the
Governor were State Comptroller
Louis Goldstein, Dr. Ralph John,
President of MICUA and Western
Maryland College, several other
college presidents, and Mr. Philip
Pear.
Woodworth quoted Goldstein
as saying that, while final budget
figures have been delayed by the
chaos of the energy crisis a final
decision on the Pear proposal
would be made in the near
future. The Governor's annual
budget proposal is cloaked in
secrecy until its formal
presentation to the General
Assembly in January.
Woodworth said that the
encouragement among MICUA
members came primarily from
Mandel's offer to present the
Pear reform as an administration
bill— contingent on the
availability of funds. Previous
bills of this nature have not been
introduced by the President of
the Senate and the Speaker of
the House.
